This is important, might as well repost it here since ZeroMe can't do that like other social media. From Firebox:

How to block a person on ZeroMe

    Find the public key of the person you want to block.
    Find the folder named after that public key in the hub folder.
    Go into that person's folder and look at data.json. Make sure that person is the right person you want to block.
    Delete all his or her files, including content.json. Then immediately make a content.json folder at the same place to prevent that file from showing up again.
    You cannot see that person's posts and comments anymore.

How much? I'm not fluent but I've studied japanese for 2 years, in a school.

@Flyman: I can read kana. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kana and a few kanji https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanji , 20 or so. Kana is easy, kanji is very hard. I know basic words for colors and animals. You can try using a dictionary like http://jisho.org/ . Japanese people write them with a pen or a pencil :) just kidding, they have a sequence to follow, this is taught in schools and there are books about it, too, every character has a proper sequence of traces, basically. And "aka" ( èµ¤ or ã‚ã‹ ) is "red" as a noum. "akai" ( èµ¤ or ã‚ã‹ã„ ) is "red" as an adjective. "akari" ( æ˜ or ã‚ã‹ã‚Š ) means "bright". These are different kanji with a similar sound, but very different meanings. And first writing is in kanji (more commonplace) and the second one is in kana (can also be used, specially for kids who still didn't learn those kanji). Kanji is very hard and takes a lot of time to learn enough of them just to read a newspaper, I still can't read them. I use some OCR add-on like "perapera" for Firefox to read them for me and get their kana.

@Flyman: if you want to write japanese characters in a computer, you have to install an IME to do that. I recommend Google IME for that https://www.google.com/ime/ since it's available for more than one OS and is integrated with their search base, so you can try searching for the appropriated kanji, but it's only in japanese, you have to understand some japanese to understand the search. I even double-check the kanji with jisho.org or some other dictionary.

- So, "kana", as it was explained in that wikipedia article I've shown you (please, read it, it's good), is the japanese syllabic writing system. It's subdivided into "hiragana" and "katakana", yes. I just use the "kana" word because it's way shorter and still describes both systems altogether precisely. It's a japanese thing, so to speak.
- Ok, any IME integrated into the OS may be good enough to type in japanese, specially if you're offline. But Google IME can search for words while still typing it, and shows sentence and kanji examples. It's all up to what you want. I still like Google IME better.
- The ã‚ˆ particle indicates, among other things, an emphasis in this case, to get someone's attention. In the end of a sentence, it means something like "REALLY, good luck with that". Literally, the sentence means "REALLY, go for it!" or something like that. It's similar to the ã­ particle, which is used a lot in japanese. ã‚ˆ is also very common. You may use either one in this case, your choice.
- I`m not so sure of the akari kanji case, or other kanji, but I know this happens a lot, in either cases, sometimes I see sentences using just the kanji and others, the kanji and complementary kana. I'm not so sure, I'm gonna check it with other people fluent in japanese and I'll answer about it later.

- Just remember that japanese is a language formed with other costumes from another country. So, words will have to be adapted to our comprehension. Maybe it's the same for russian, I guess, I don't know any russian. In "konnichiwa", it really means like that because the japanese people say "konnichiwa" to each other starting from 10AM. Before 10AM, it is "ohayougozaimasu". Some people translate "konnichiwa" like "good afternoon", but it's not entirely correct since it starts at 10AM. It's some japanese people's costume, it works for the japanese this way, I don't know why. Always remember: "another language to learn means to learn new costumes and cultures together". Also, the ã¯ particle is one of the hard to understand cases in japanese, but yes, ã¯ (ha) can be pronounced like (wa) in some cases. And konnichiwa can be written in both forms, both are correct, but ä»Šæ—¥ã¯ is more formal and more common. ä»Šæ—¥ã‚ is rare and not formal, from what I know.
